results.title: Origin of land plants: liverworts and mosses
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program. Unit 2. Plant life”.
Traces the evolution of land plants and illustrates the structural characteristics, reproductive processes and adaptive mechanisms of liverworts and mosses. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Origami
results.creator_credit: Joan Hanson, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The Japanese art of paper folding, as practised both by skilled fingers and the less-adept hands of children. That anyone can learn and experiment, and take pleasure from the results, is evident from the variety of shapes and figures being conjured out of colored paper.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Hanson, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: David Copperfield
results.creator_credit: Simon Curtis, Kate Harwood and BBC
results.brief_description: Charles Dicken’s classic tale of the boy whose life is changed irrevocable when his mother marries the cruel Mr Murdstone, only to die and leave her son in his sinister clutches is brought to life in this BBC production which includes a stellar cast of Bob Hoskins, Maggie Smith, Betsey Trotwood, Trevor Eve, Nicholas Lyndhurst, Pauline Quirke, Ian Holm and Ciaran McMenamin as David.

results.title: Orfeo and Euridice
results.creator_credit: Peter Hall, Rodney Greenberg, Glyndebourne Productions and TVS
results.brief_description: This recorded production of Christoph Willibald von Gluck’s “Orfeo and Euridice”, original text by Ramierie de’Calzabigi, is presented by the Glyndebourne Festival Opera with an introduction by Dame Janet Baker. It is a tale of Greek mythology after the classic legend, Orpheus and stars singer Janet Blake, as Orfeo, in her farewell performance on the operatic stage, along with Elisabeth Speiser as Euridice and Elizabeth Gale as Amore. Features the Glyndebourne Festival Chorus and the London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Raymond Leppard in a new staging production by Peter Hall. Sung in Italian. Includes a guide with English translation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Hall, Rodney Greenberg, Glyndebourne Productions and TVS

results.title: Dating the enemy
results.creator_credit: Megan Simpson, Sue Milliken and Total Films
results.brief_description: Guy Pearce and Claudia Karvan star in this comedy which looks at the battle between the sexes from a new perspective. Brett and Tash fall in love but when a lack of compromise threatens their relationship, the forces of the universe intervene. One day they awake to find themselves prisoners in each other’s bodies. Brett learns that being a woman, particularly Tash, presents its own challenges, while Tash learns more than she had bargained for about the male psyche.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Megan Simpson, Sue Milliken and Total Films

results.title: David Anderson: works on film
results.creator_credit: David Anderson, David Jeffcock, Barnaby Spurrier, James Bradley and Redwing
results.brief_description: David Anderson is one of the Uk’s leading animators, and in this collection his creative and technical range is given full rein. The program begins with Anderson’s BAFTA Award-winning debut film “Dreamland express” (1982) which captures the rich fantasy life of childhood. “Sweet disaster, dreamless sleep” (1986) is a poignant allegory on the theme of the nuclear nightmare. “Deadtime stories for big folk” is the title of a collaboration between Anderson and the novelist Russell Hoban, and a documentary on this includes the full versions of the two films involved, “Deadsy” (1989) and “Door” (1990). Both have won many awards and are powerful and disturbing pieces.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Anderson, David Jeffcock, Barnaby Spurrier, James Bradley and Redwing

results.title: Das Duracellband
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: In this dynamic collage, vom Bruch assembles powerful metaphors for threat and force, using fragmented, repeated images from media advertising and archival documents from World War II. The central image, appropriated from a popular TV commercial, is both riveting and ironic: A Duracell battery snaps together with a loud crack. This violent action, which is repeated over and over again, is intercut with flash-frame glimpses of the Nagasaki explosion, an American bomber pilot, aerial views of wartime destruction, victims of the nuclear bomb, and the artist’s face. Vom Bruch constructs a landscape of associations through mediated images, building relational discourse on the violence of war and capital. Through the aggressive confluence of advertising, World War II destruction and self-images, vom Bruch positions contemporary identity within the context of the representational and historical apparatuses of the military and the mass media, as signifiers of collective memory.

results.title: David
results.creator_credit: Steve Mason and Religious Film Society
results.brief_description: David Ellis, a 19 year old physically and mentally handicapped person, shares his relationship to everyday situations. The effect of his disability on family and personal relationships. A strongly religious film.

results.title: Orphee et Eurydice
results.creator_credit: Peter Butler, Stefanos Lazaridis, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Opera Australia
results.brief_description: Orphee et Eurydice, directed by Stefanos Lazaridis, music by Christoph Willibald Gluck, libretto by Ranierie da Calzabigi, and adapted for the French performing edition by Pierre-Louis Moline, tells the tale of lovers separated by death. Orphee must go on a quest to Hades to find his dead wife Eurydice and bring her back to the living. The voyage is full of peril, and it is only after much heartache that he is reunited with his own true love. Features singers David Hobson (Orphee), Miriam Gormley (L’Amour), Amanda Thane (Eurydice), and The Australian Opera Chorus. Also features the Dancers of the Meryl Tankard Australian Dance Theatre and Dancers of The Australian Opera choreographed by Meryl Tankard, and The Australian Opera and Ballet Orchestra conducted by Marco Guidarini. Recorded live at the Sydney Opera House on 20 September 1993 and produced for television in association with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Sung in French with English subtitles.
